  Text content: Dear Members of the Harvard Community, For three-quarters of a century, the federal government has awarded grants and contracts to Harvard and other universities to help pay for work that, along with investments by the universities themselves, has led to groundbreaking innovations across a wide range of medical, engineering, and scientific fields. These innovations have made countless people in our country and throughout the world healthier and safer. In recent weeks, the federal government has threatened its partnerships with several universities, including Harvard, over accusations of antisemitism on our campuses. These partnerships are among the most productive and beneficial in American history. New frontiers beckon us with the prospect of life-changing advances—from treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and diabetes, to breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, quantum science and engineering, and numerous other areas of possibility. For the government to retreat from these partnerships now risks not only the health and well-being of millions of individuals but also the economic security and vitality of our nation.

edit target content:
Summarize text in a specific text box :
Please summarize the text in the specified text box on ppt slides number  in a simpler way.

Dear Members of the Harvard Community,
 
For three-quarters of a century, the federal government has awarded grants and contracts to Harvard and other universities to help pay for work that, along with investments by the universities themselves, has led to groundbreaking innovations across a wide range of medical, engineering, and scientific fields. These innovations have made countless people in our country and throughout the world healthier and safer. In recent weeks, the federal government has threatened its partnerships with several universities, including Harvard, over accusations of antisemitism on our campuses. These partnerships are among the most productive and beneficial in American history. New frontiers beckon us with the prospect of life-changing advances—from treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and diabetes, to breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, quantum science and engineering, and numerous other areas of possibility. For the government to retreat from these partnerships now risks not only the health and well-being of millions of individuals but also the economic security and vitality of our nation.
content after edit:
특정 텍스트 상자에 있는 텍스트 요약하기 :
PPT 슬라이드의 지정된 텍스트 상자에 있는 텍스트를 더 쉽게 요약해 주세요.

하버드 커뮤니티 여러분께,

75년 동안 연방 정부는 하버드와 다른 대학들에게 연구를 지원하기 위한 보조금과 계약을 제공해 왔습니다. 대학 자체의 투자와 함께 이 지원은 의학, 공학, 과학 분야에서 획기적인 혁신을 가능하게 했으며, 이는 우리나라와 전 세계의 수많은 사람들의 건강과 안전을 증진시켰습니다. 최근 몇 주간 연방 정부는 캠퍼스 내 반유대주의 혐의로 인해 하버드를 포함한 여러 대학과의 협력을 위협하고 있습니다. 이러한 협력은 미국 역사상 가장 생산적이고 유익한 파트너십 중 하나입니다. 알츠하이머, 파킨슨, 당뇨병 치료법부터 인공지능, 양자 과학 및 공학 등 다양한 분야에서 삶을 변화시키는 발전이 우리를 기다리고 있습니다. 정부가 지금 이러한 협력에서 물러난다면 수백만 명의 건강과 복지뿐 아니라 국가의 경제적 안정과 활력도 위태로워질 것입니다.

These innovations have made countless people in our country and throughout the world healthier and safer. These partnerships are among the most productive and beneficial in American history. New frontiers beckon us with the prospect of life-changing advances—from treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and diabetes, to breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, quantum science and engineering, and numerous other areas of possibility. Dear Members of the Harvard Community,
 
For three-quarters of a century, the federal government has awarded grants and contracts to Harvard and other universities to help pay for work that, along with investments by the universities themselves, has led to groundbreaking innovations across a wide range of medical, engineering, and scientific fields. These innovations have made countless people in our country and throughout the world healthier and safer. In recent weeks, the federal government has threatened its partnerships with several universities, including Harvard, over accusations of antisemitism on our campuses. These partnerships are among the most productive and beneficial in American history. New frontiers beckon us with the prospect of life-changing advances—from treatments for diseases such as Alzheimer’s, Parkinson’s, and diabetes, to breakthroughs in artificial intelligence, quantum science and engineering, and numerous other areas of possibility. For the government to retreat from these partnerships now risks not only the health and well-being of millions of individuals but also the economic security and vitality of our nation.
